Since Shriram is carrying on a scheduled industry, it is subject to this stringent system of regis tration and licensing.
It is also amenable.
to various directions that may be issued by the Government from time to time and it is subject to the exercise of the powers of the Government under Sections 18A, and 18G. Shriram is required to obtain a licence under the Facto ries Act and is subject to the directions and orders of the authorities under the Act.
It is also required to obtain a licence for its manufacturing activities from the Municipal authorities under the Delhi Municipal Act, 1957.
It is subject to extensive environment regulation under the and as the factory is situated in an air pollution control area, it is also subject to the regulation of the Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981.
It is true that control is not exercised by the Government in relation to the internal management policies of the Company.
However, the control is exercised on all such activities of Shriram which can jeop ardize public interest.
This functional control is of spe cial significance as it is the potentiality of the fertiliz er industry to adversely affect the health and safety of the community and its being impregnated with public interest which perhaps dictated the policy decision of the Government to ultimately operate this industry exclusively and invited functional control.
Along with this extensive functional control, we find that Shriram also receives sizable assist ance in the shape of loans and overdrafts running into several crores of rupees from the Government through various agencies.
Moreover, Shriram is engaged in the manufacture of caustic soda, chlorine etc.
Its various units are set up in a single complex surrounded by thickly populated colonies.
Chlorine gas is admittedly dangerous to life and ' health.
If the gas escapes either from the storage tank or from the filled cylinders or from any other point in the course of production, the health and wellbeing of the people living in the vicinity can be seriously affected.
Thus Shriram is engaged in an activity which has the potential to invade the right to life of large sections of people.
The question is whether these factors are cumulatively sufficient to bring Shriram within the ambit of Article 12.
Prima facie it is arguable that when the States ' power as economic agent, economic entrepreneur and allocator of economic benefits is subject to the limitations of fundamental rights.
(Vide 840 Eurasian Equipment and Chemicals Ltd. vs State of West Bengal, ; , Rashbehari Panda vs State, , Ramanna Shetty vs International Airport Authori ty, (supra) and Kasturilal Reddy vs State of Jammu & Kash mir; , why should a private corporation under the functional control of the State engaged in an activity which is hazardous to the health and safety of the community and is imbued with public interest and which the State ultimately proposes to exclusively run under its industrial policy, not be subject to the same limitations.
But we do not propose to decide this question and make any definite pronouncement upon it for reasons which we shall point out later in the course of this judgment.
We were during the course of arguments, addressed at great length by counsel on both sides on the American doc trine of State action.
The learned counsel elaborately traced the evolution of this doctrine in its parent country.
We are aware that in America since the Fourteenth Amendment is available only against the State, the Courts, in order to thwart racial discrimination by private parties, devised the theory of State action under which it was held that wherever private activity was aided, facilitated or supported by the Slate in a significant measure, such activity took the colour of State action and was subject to the constitutional limitations of the Fourteenth Amendment.
This historical context in which the doctrine of State action evolved in the United States is irrelevant for our purpose especially since we have Article 15(2) in our Constitution.
But it is the principle behind the doctrine of State aid, control and regulation so impregnating a private activity as to give it the colour of State action that is of interest to us and that also to the limited extent to which it can be Indian ized and harmoniously blended with our constitutional juris prudence.
That we in no way consider ourselves bound by American exposition of constitutional law is well demos trated by the fact that in Ramanna Shetty, (supra) this Court preferred the minority opinion of Douglas, J. in Jackson vs Metropolitan Edison Company, ; as against the majority opinion of Rehnquist, J. And again in Air India vs Nargesh Mirza, ; this Court whilst preferring the minority view in General Electric Company Martha vs Gilbert, ; said that the provisions of the American Constitution cannot always be applied to Indian conditions or to the provisions of our Constitution and whilst some of the principles adumbrated by the American decisions may provide a useful guide, close adherence to those principles while applying them to the provisions of our Constitution is not to be favoured, be cause the social conditions in our country are different.
The learned counsel for Shriram stressed the inapposite 841 ness of the doctrine of State action in the Indian context because, according to him, once an authority is brought within the purview of Article 12, it is State for all in tents and purposes and the functional dichotomy in America where certain activities of the same authority may be cha raterised as State action and others as private action cannot be applied here in India.
But so far as this argument is concerned, we must demur to it and point out that it is not correct to say that in India once a corporation is deemed to be 'authority ', it would be subject to the consti tutional limitation of fundamental rights in the performance of all its functions and that the appellation of 'authority ' would stick to such corporation, irrespective of the func tional context.
Before we part with this topic, we may point out that this Court has throughout the last few years expanded the horizon of Article 12 primarily to inject respect for human rights and social conscience in our corporate struc ture.
The purpose of expansion has not been to destroy the raison d 'eter of creating corporations but to advance the human rights jurisprudence.
Prima facie we are not inclined to accept the apprehensions of learned counsel for Shriram as well founded when he says that our including within the ambit of Article 12 and thus subjecting to the discipline of Article 21, those private corporations whose activities have the potential of affecting the life and health of the peo ple, would deal a death blow to the policy of encouraging and permitting private entrepreneurial activity.
Whenever a new advance is made in the field of human rights, apprehen sion is always expressed by the status quosits that it will create enormous difficulties in the way of smooth function ing of the system and affect its stability.
Similar appre hension was voiced when this Court In Ramanna Shetty 's case (supra) brought public sector corporations within the scope and ambit of Article 12 and subjected them to the discipline of fundamental rights.
Such apprehension expressed by those who may be affected by any new and innovative expansion of human rights need not deter the Court from widening the scope of human rights and expanding their reach ambit, if otherwise it is possible to do so without doing violence to the language of the constitutional provision.
It is through creative interpretation and bold innovation that the human rights jurisprudence has been developed in our country to a remarkable extent and this forward march of the human rights movement cannot be allowed to be halted by unfounded appre hensions expressed by status quoists.
But we do not propose to decide finally at the present stage whether a private corporation like Shriram would fall within the scope and ambit of Article 12, because we have not had sufficient time to consider and reflect on this question in depth The hearing of this case before us 842 concluded only on 15th December 1986 and we are called upon to deliver our judgment within a period of four days, on 19th December 1986.
We are therefore of the view that this is not a question on which we must make any definite pro nouncement at this stage.
But we would leave it for a proper and detailed consideration at a later stage if it becomes necessary to do so.
We must also deal with one other question which was seriously debated before us and that question is as to what is the measure of liability of an enterprise which is en gaged in an hazardous or inherently dangerous industry, if by reason of an accident occurring in such industry, persons die or are injured.
Does the rule in Rylands vs Fletcher apply or is there any other principle on which the liability can be determined? The rule in Rylands vs Fletcher was evolved in the year 1866 and it provides that a person who for his own purposes being on to his land and collects and keeps there anything likely to do mischief if it escapes must keep it at his peril and, if he falls to do so, is prima facie liable for the damage which is the natural consequence of its escape.
The liability under this rule is strict and it is no defence that the thing escaped without that person 's wilful act, default or neglect or even that he had no knowledge of its existence.
This rule laid down a principle of liability that if a person who brings on to his land and collects and keeps there anything likely to do harm and such thing escapes and does damage to another, he is liable to compensate for the damage caused.
Of course, this rule applies only to non natural user of the land and it does not apply to things naturally on the land or where the escape is due to an act of God and an act of a stranger or the default of the person injured or where the thing which escapes is present by the consent of the person injured or in certain cases where there is statutory authority.
Vide Halsbury Laws of England, Vol.
45 para 1305.
Considerable case law has developed in England as to what is natural and what is non natural use of land and what are precisely the circumstances in which this rule may be displaced.
But it is not necessary for us to consider these decisions laying down the parameters of this rule because in a modern industrial society with highly developed scientific knowledge and technology where hazardous or inherently dangerous indus tries are necessary to carry out part of the developmental programme.
This rule evolved in the 19th Century at a time when all these developments of science and technology had not taken place cannot afford any guidance in evolving any standard of liability consistent with the constitutional norms and the needs of the present day economy and social structure.
We need not feel inhibited by this rule which was evolved in this context of a totally different kind of 843 economy.
Law has to grow in order to satisfy the needs of the fast changing society and keep abreast with the economic developments taking place in the country.
As new situations arise the law has to be evolved in order to meet the chal lenge of such new situations.
Law cannot afford to remain static.
We have to evolve new principles and lay down new norms Which would adequately deal with the new problems which arise in a highly industrialised economy.
We cannot allow our judicial thinking to be constricted by reference to the law as it prevails in England or for the matter of that in any other foreign country.
We no longer need the crutches of a foreign legal order.
We are certainly prepared to receive light from whatever source it comes but we have to build up our own jurisprudence and we cannot countenance an argument that merely because the new law does not recog nise the rule of strict and absolute liability in cases of hazardous or dangerous liability or the rule as laid down in Rylands vs Fletcher as is developed in England recognises certain limitations and responsibilities.
We in India cannot hold our hands back and I venture to evolve a new.
principle of liability which English courts have not done.
We have to develop our own law and if we find that it is necessary to construct a new principle of liability to deal with an unusual situation which has arisen and which is likely to arise in future on account of hazardous or inherently dan gerous industries which are concommitant to an industrial economy, there is no reason why we should hesitate to evolve such principle of liability merely because it has not been so done in England.
We are of the view that an enterprise which is engaged in a hazardous or inherently dangerous industry which poses a potential threat to the health and safety of the persons working in the factory and residing in the surrounding areas owes an absolute and nondelegable duty to the community to ensure that no harm results to anyone on account of hazardous or inherently dangerous nature of the activity which it has undertaken.
The enterprise must be held to be under an obligation to provide that the hazardous or inherently dangerous activity in which it is engaged must be conducted with the highest standards of safety and if any harm results on account of such activity, the enterprise must be absolutely liable to compensate for such harm and it should be no answer to the enterprise to say that it had taken all reasonable care and that the harm occurred without any negligence on its part.
Since the persons harmed on account of the hazardous or inherently dangerous activity carried on by the enterprise would not be in a position to isolate the process of operation from the hazardous prepara tion of substance or any other related element that caused the harm must be held strictly liable for causing such harm as a part of the social cost for carrying on the hazardous or 844 inherently dangerous activity.
If the enterprise is permit ted to carry on an hazardous or inherently dangerous activi ty for its profit, the law must presume that such permission is conditional on the enterprise absorbing the cost of any accident arising on account of such hazardous or inherently dangerous activity as an appropriate item of its over heads.
Such hazardous or inherently dangerous activity for private profit can be tolerated only on condition that the enter prise engaged in such hazardous or inherently dangerous activity indemnifies all those who suffer on account of the carrying on of such hazardous or inherently dangerous activ ity regardless of whether it is carried on carefully or not.
This principle is also sustainable on the ground that the enterprise alone has the resource to discover and guard against hazards or dangers and to provide warning against potential hazards.
We would therefore hold that where an enterprise is engaged in a hazardous or inherently dangerous activity and harm results to anyone on account of an acci dent in the operation of such hazardous or inherently dan gerous activity resulting, for example, in escape of toxic gas the enterprise is strictly and absolutely liable to compensate all those who are affected by the accident and such liability is not subject to any of the exceptions which operate vis a vis the tortious principle of strict liability under the rule in Rylands vs Fletcher (supra).
We would also like to point out that the measure of compensation in the kind of cases referred to in the preced ing paragraph must be co related to the magnitude and capac ity of the enterprise because such compensation must have a deferent effect.
The larger and more prosperous the enter prise, the greater must be the amount of compensation pay able by it for the harm caused on account of an accident in the carrying on of the hazardous or inherently dangerous activity by the enterprise.
Since we are not deciding the question as to whether Shriram is an authority within the meaning of Article 12 so as to be subjected to the discipline of the fundamental right under Article 21, we do not think it would be justi fied in setting up a special machinery for investigation of the claims for compensation made by those who allege that they have been the victims of oleum gas escape.
But we would direct that Delhi Legal Aid and Advice Board to take up the cases of all those who claim to have suffered on account of oleum gas and to file actions on their behalf in the appro priate court for claiming compensation against Shriram.
Such actions claiming compensation may be filed by the Delhi Legal Aid and Advice Board.within two months from 845 today and the Delhi Administration is directed to provide the necessary funds to the Delhi Legal Aid and Advice Board for the purpose of filing and prosecuting such actions.
The High Court will nominate one or more Judges as may be neces sary for the purpose of trying such actions so that they may be expeditiously disposed of.
So far as the issue of reloca tion and other issues are concerned the writ petition will come up for hearing on 3rd February, 1987.
A.P.J. Petition dis posed of.

qa_pairs.question: What was the number of the Writ Petition?
qa_pairs.answer: The number of the Writ Petition was (Civil) No. 12739 of 1985.

qa_pairs.question: Under which Article of the Constitution of India was the petition filed?
qa_pairs.answer: The petition was filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

qa_pairs.question: Who appeared as the petitioner in person?
qa_pairs.answer: The petitioner appeared in person.

qa_pairs.question: Who were some of the Additional Solicitor Generals and Senior Advocates appearing for the Respondents?
qa_pairs.answer: B. Datta, F.S. Nariman, and Soli J. Sorabji were some of the advocates for the Respondents.

qa_pairs.question: Who appeared as an intervener?
qa_pairs.answer: Raju Ramachandran appeared for the Intervener.

qa_pairs.question: Who appeared for the Citizens Action Committee?
qa_pairs.answer: Soli J. Sorabji appeared for the Citizens Action Committee.

qa_pairs.question: Who delivered the Judgment of the Court?
qa_pairs.answer: Chief Justice Bhagwati delivered the Judgment of the Court.

qa_pairs.question: Why did the writ petition come before a Bench of five Judges?
qa_pairs.answer: It came before a larger Bench of five Judges on a reference made by a Bench of three Judges because certain questions of seminal importance and high constitutional significance were raised.

qa_pairs.question: When did the Bench of three Judges give its initial judgment in the case?
qa_pairs.answer: The Bench of three Judges gave its judgment on 17th February 1986.

qa_pairs.question: What was the main relief sought in the original writ petition?
qa_pairs.answer: The main relief sought was a direction for the closure of the various units of Shriram Foods and Fertiliser Industries.

qa_pairs.question: What was the ground for seeking the closure of Shriram's units?
qa_pairs.answer: The ground was that the units were hazardous to the community.

qa_pairs.question: What was the surviving point in dispute after the initial judgment?
qa_pairs.answer: Whether the units of Shriram should be removed from their present location and relocated to a less populated area.

qa_pairs.question: When did the escape of oleum gas from Shriram's unit occur?
qa_pairs.answer: The escape of oleum gas occurred on 4th and 6th December, 1985.

qa_pairs.question: Which organizations filed applications for compensation for the victims of the oleum gas leak?
qa_pairs.answer: The Delhi Legal Aid & Advice Board and the Delhi Bar Association filed the applications for compensation.

qa_pairs.question: What was the nature of the issues raised by the applications for compensation?
qa_pairs.answer: The applications raised a number of issues of great constitutional importance.

qa_pairs.question: Which Articles of the Constitution were specifically mentioned as being related to the substantial questions of law involved?
qa_pairs.answer: Articles 21 and 32 of the Constitution were mentioned.

qa_pairs.question: What preliminary objection was raised by Mr. Diwan on behalf of Shriram?
qa_pairs.answer: He objected to the Court deciding the constitutional issues since no claim for compensation was originally made in the writ petition.

qa_pairs.question: Did Mr. Diwan concede that the oleum gas leak occurred after the filing of the writ petition?
qa_pairs.answer: Yes, Mr. Diwan conceded this point.

qa_pairs.question: What was Mr. Diwan's argument regarding the lack of an amendment to the writ petition?
qa_pairs.answer: His argument was that since the petitioner did not apply for amendment to include a compensation claim, the constitutional issues did not arise on the writ petition as it stood.

qa_pairs.question: Did the Court find Mr. Diwan's preliminary objection sustainable?
qa_pairs.answer: No, the Court did not think the preliminary objection was sustainable.

qa_pairs.question: What fundamental right did the applications for compensation seek to enforce?
qa_pairs.answer: The fundamental right to life enshrined in Article 21 of the Constitution.

qa_pairs.question: What approach did the Court state it cannot adopt when dealing with applications for enforcement of fundamental rights?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court stated it cannot adopt a hypertechnical approach that would defeat the ends of justice.

qa_pairs.question: What has the Court pointed out regarding actions brought by public-spirited individuals for the disadvantaged?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court has pointed out that such individuals or social action groups can bring actions for vindication of fundamental or other legal rights, even through letters to the Court.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Court's view on entertaining letters complaining of fundamental rights violations?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court is prepared to accept such letters from individuals or classes unable to approach the Court for justice.

qa_pairs.question: What principle does the Court emphasize when dealing with applications for enforcement of fundamental rights?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court emphasizes looking at the substance and not the form.

qa_pairs.question: What was the first question the Court deemed necessary to consider?
qa_pairs.answer: The scope and ambit of the jurisdiction of the Court under Article 32.

qa_pairs.question: In which case did the Court previously consider the ambit of Article 32?
qa_pairs.answer: Bandhua Mukti Morcha vs Union of India & Ors.

qa_pairs.question: What constitutional obligation does Article 32 lay on the Court?
qa_pairs.answer: To protect the fundamental rights of the people.

qa_pairs.question: What incidental and ancillary powers does the Court have under Article 32 for protecting fundamental rights?
qa_pairs.answer: The power to forge new remedies and fashion new strategies designed to enforce fundamental rights.

qa_pairs.question: In which case did the Court hold that public-spirited individuals can maintain applications for legal wrongs suffered by the disadvantaged?
qa_pairs.answer: S.P. Gupta vs Union of India.

qa_pairs.question: What did the Court reiterate in S.P. Gupta's case and other cases regarding procedure?
qa_pairs.answer: That procedure is merely a handmaiden of justice and should not obstruct access to justice for the weaker sections.

qa_pairs.question: What is the 'epistolary jurisdiction' that the Court refers to?
qa_pairs.answer: The jurisdiction invoked by letters addressed to the Court, especially on behalf of the poor and disadvantaged.

qa_pairs.question: What apprehension did some justices have in Bandhua Mukti Morcha's case regarding letters addressed to individual justices?
qa_pairs.answer: They apprehended that it might involve the court in frivolous cases and that such letters might not invoke the jurisdiction of the whole court.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Court's current view on rejecting letters addressed to individual justices?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court does not think it would be right to reject such letters merely based on the form of address.

qa_pairs.question: Why should letters addressed to individual judges be entertained?
qa_pairs.answer: Because poor and disadvantaged persons or social action groups may not know the proper form of address and might only know a particular judge.

qa_pairs.question: What mechanism does the Court now have for handling letters addressed to individual justices?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court has a Public Interest Litigation Cell that receives and scrutinizes all such letters before listing them before the Court under the Chief Justice's direction.

qa_pairs.question: Should letters be rejected solely for not conforming to the preferred form of address?
qa_pairs.answer: No, letters should not be rejected merely for this reason.

qa_pairs.question: Does the Court insist on an affidavit as a condition for entertaining letters?
qa_pairs.answer: No, insisting on an affidavit would frustrate the object and purpose of epistolary jurisdiction.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Court's experience regarding the truthfulness of allegations made in letters?
qa_pairs.answer: So far, the Court has been entertaining letters without affidavits, and only in rare cases have the allegations been found false, which can also happen in regular litigation.

qa_pairs.question: What does the Court endorse regarding its power under Article 32 to gather relevant material and appoint Commissions in social action litigation?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court endorses what Justice Bhagwati said in his judgment in Bandhua Mukti Morcha's case on this matter.

qa_pairs.question: What freedom does Article 32(1) give the Court regarding procedure?
qa_pairs.answer: It gives the Court the freedom to devise any procedure appropriate for enforcing a fundamental right.

qa_pairs.question: What implicit power does the Court have under Article 32(2)?
qa_pairs.answer: The power to issue whatever direction, order, or writ is necessary, including all incidental or ancillary powers to secure enforcement of fundamental rights.

qa_pairs.question: Is the Court's power under Article 32 only injunctive?
qa_pairs.answer: No, it is also remedial in scope and provides relief against a breach of a fundamental right already committed.

qa_pairs.question: What would be the consequence if the Court were powerless to act when a fundamental right has already been violated?
qa_pairs.answer: Article 32 would be robbed of all its efficacy.

qa_pairs.question: Can the Court grant remedial relief, including compensation, under Article 32?
qa_pairs.answer: Yes, the power of the Court to grant such relief may include the power to award compensation in appropriate cases.

qa_pairs.question: Does the Court award compensation in every case where there is a breach of a fundamental right?
qa_pairs.answer: No, compensation is awarded in 'appropriate cases' where the infringement is gross and patent.

qa_pairs.question: What are some of the circumstances under which the Court might award compensation under Article 32?
qa_pairs.answer: When the infringement is gross, patent, incontrovertible, ex facie glaring, on a large scale, or appears unjust or unduly harsh due to poverty, disability, or social/economic disadvantage.

qa_pairs.question: Should a petition under Article 32 ordinarily be used as a substitute for claiming compensation through civil courts?
qa_pairs.answer: No, ordinarily it should not be used as a substitute.

qa_pairs.question: In which cases did the Court award compensation for the violation of fundamental rights?
qa_pairs.answer: Rudul Shah vs State of Bihar and the case of Bhim Singh.

qa_pairs.question: What was the common thread in the cases where the Court awarded compensation?
qa_pairs.answer: The fact of infringement was patent and incontrovertible, the violation was gross and shocking to the conscience, and requiring the victim to go to civil court would be gravely unjust.

qa_pairs.question: What was the next question for consideration regarding the applications for compensation?
qa_pairs.answer: Whether Article 21 is available against Shriram, a public company engaged in a vital industry with potential to affect public life and health.

qa_pairs.question: What was the applicants' argument for Article 21 being applicable to Shriram?
qa_pairs.answer: Using the analogy of the American doctrine of State Action and the functional/control test, they argued that Shriram's industry was intended to be carried out by the government and was under active government control.

qa_pairs.question: What was the emphasis placed by the applicants' counsel regarding the regulatory mechanism?
qa_pairs.answer: They emphasized the regulatory framework under the Industries Development and Regulation Act, Bombay Municipal Corporation Act, Pollution Control Acts, and the Environment Act.

qa_pairs.question: What other forms of government support to Shriram did the applicants' counsel point out?
qa_pairs.answer: Sizable aid in loans, land, and other facilities.

qa_pairs.question: What was the argument based on the American State Action doctrine?
qa_pairs.answer: That private activity supported, controlled, or regulated by the State can become so entwined with governmental activity as to be termed State action, subject to constitutional restraints.

qa_pairs.question: What caution did Shriram's counsel raise against expanding Article 12?
qa_pairs.answer: He cautioned against bringing private corporations within its ambit.

qa_pairs.question: What did Shriram's counsel contend regarding state control under general statutory law?
qa_pairs.answer: He argued it's merely an exercise of police power and doesn't convert the private corporation's activity into that of the State.

qa_pairs.question: What type of control did Shriram's counsel argue would deem a corporation an agency of the State?
qa_pairs.answer: Control over the management policies, such as sizable representation on the board or prior government approval for new policies.

qa_pairs.question: What was Shriram's counsel's argument regarding the inappositeness of the State action doctrine to the Indian situation?
qa_pairs.answer: He argued that in India, the control and function test determines if an authority is an instrumentality of the State under Article 12, and once deemed so, all its activities are 'State action'.

qa_pairs.question: What specific fundamental rights against private parties did Shriram's counsel point out in the Constitution?
qa_pairs.answer: Articles 17 (abolition of untouchability), 23 (prohibition of forced labor), and 24 (prohibition of child labor).

qa_pairs.question: What was Shriram's counsel's conclusion about expanding Article 12 to include private corporations?
qa_pairs.answer: He argued it would be against the scheme of the Chapter on fundamental rights.

qa_pairs.question: In which case did the Court first embark on evolving criteria for terming a corporation 'other authority' under Article 12?
qa_pairs.answer: Rajasthan Electricity Board vs Mohan Lal.

qa_pairs.question: What did Justice Bhargava state was included in 'other authorities' in Rajasthan Electricity Board's case?
qa_pairs.answer: All constitutional and statutory authorities on whom powers are conferred by law.

qa_pairs.question: What was Justice Shah's slightly different meaning for 'other authorities'?
qa_pairs.answer: Authorities, constitutional or statutory, invested with the sovereign power of the State, namely, the power to make rules and regulations with the force of law.

qa_pairs.question: What was the ratio of the decision in Rajasthan Electricity Board vs Mohan Lal?
qa_pairs.answer: A constitutional or statutory authority is within 'other authorities' if it has statutory power to issue binding directions with penal consequences or sovereign power to make laws.

qa_pairs.question: Who followed the test laid down in Rajasthan Electricity Board's case in Sukhdev vs Bhagat Ram?
qa_pairs.answer: Chief Justice Ray.

qa_pairs.question: What broader test did Justice Mathew propound in Sukhdev vs Bhagat Ram?
qa_pairs.answer: That a public corporation being an instrumentality of the 'State' is subject to the same constitutional limitations as the 'State' itself, provided it's created by the 'State' and has the power to invade constitutional rights.

qa_pairs.question: In which case did the Court accept and adopt Justice Mathew's instrumentality or agency of State rationale?
qa_pairs.answer: Ramanna Shetty vs International Airport Authority.

qa_pairs.question: What concern did Justice Mathew's broader test address?
qa_pairs.answer: The need to curb arbitrary and unregulated power wherever and however reposed.

qa_pairs.question: Did the Court in Ramanna D. Shetty's case formulate an exhaustive test to determine if a corporation is an instrumentality of the government?
qa_pairs.answer: No, the Court said it was not possible to formulate an all-inclusive or exhaustive test.

qa_pairs.question: From which concept did the Court say analogical aid could be taken?
qa_pairs.answer: The concept of State Action as developed in the United States.

qa_pairs.question: What kind of State assistance is generally not considered to transform private conduct into State Action?
qa_pairs.answer: The State's general common law and statutory structure under which people carry on private affairs.

qa_pairs.question: What kind of financial assistance might support an inference that a corporation is a government instrumentality?
qa_pairs.answer: Extensive and unusual financial assistance whose purpose coincides with a public purpose for which the corporation is expected to use it.

qa_pairs.question: Is some control by the State over a business organization determinative of it being a State agency?
qa_pairs.answer: No, some control under police power is not determinative.

qa_pairs.question: What combination of factors might lead to characterizing an operation as State Action?
qa_pairs.answer: State financial support plus an unusual degree of control over management and policies.

qa_pairs.question: How should the classification of a function as governmental be done?
qa_pairs.answer: Not on earlier day perceptions but on what the State today views as indispensable to its activities.

qa_pairs.question: What kind of activities are considered government functions based on their importance to society?
qa_pairs.answer: Activities too fundamental to society are by definition too important not to be considered government functions.

qa_pairs.question: How many factors did the Court enumerate in R.D. Shetty's case for determining if a corporation is a State instrumentality?
qa_pairs.answer: Five factors.

qa_pairs.question: What were the five factors enumerated in R.D. Shetty's case?
qa_pairs.answer: Financial assistance, other forms of assistance, control of management and policies, State-conferred or protected monopoly, and public functions closely related to governmental functions.

qa_pairs.question: Did the Court consider the enumeration of factors in R.D. Shetty's case exhaustive?
qa_pairs.answer: No, the Court took care to point out that the enumeration was not exhaustive.

qa_pairs.question: What effect of the relevant factors must be taken as controlling?
qa_pairs.answer: The aggregate or cumulative effect of all the relevant factors.

qa_pairs.question: In which case were the criteria from Ramanna Shetty's case applied?
qa_pairs.answer: Ajay Hasia vs Khalid Mujib.

qa_pairs.question: What did the Court emphasize in Ajay Hasia's case regarding constitutional fundamentals and diagnostic tools?
qa_pairs.answer: That where constitutional fundamentals vital to human rights are at stake, functional realism, not facial cosmetics, must be the diagnostic tool, seeking substance over form.

qa_pairs.question: What analogy did the Court draw regarding the government acting through different entities?
qa_pairs.answer: That the government acts through the instrumentality of natural or judicial persons.

qa_pairs.question: What cannot be allowed to obliterate the true nature of the reality behind a corporation?
qa_pairs.answer: The juristic veil of corporate personality worn for convenience of management and administration.

qa_pairs.question: What principle regarding constitutional limitations follows if the government acting through its officers is subject to them?
qa_pairs.answer: That the government acting through a corporation should be equally subject to the same limitations.

qa_pairs.question: What canon of construction should be adopted for interpreting constitutional guarantees?
qa_pairs.answer: They should not be emasculated by narrow and constructed judicial interpretation; Courts should enlarge their scope.

qa_pairs.question: What should the Courts be anxious to bring within the sweep of fundamental rights?
qa_pairs.answer: Every authority that is an instrumentality or agency of the Government or through whose corporate personality the Government is acting.

qa_pairs.question: What controversy did the Court set at rest in Ajay Hasia's case regarding the manner of a corporation's creation?
qa_pairs.answer: Whether the manner of a corporation's creation (by statute or under a statute) has relevance to whether it's a State instrumentality.

qa_pairs.question: What is the relevant inquiry when determining if a corporation is a State instrumentality, according to Ajay Hasia's case?
qa_pairs.answer: Not how the juristic person is born but why it has been brought into existence.

qa_pairs.question: What types of entities can fall within the ambit of Article 12 if found to be instrumentalities of the State?
qa_pairs.answer: Statutory corporations, government companies, companies formed under the Companies Act, and societies registered under relevant statutes.

qa_pairs.question: What has the Court not permitted the corporate device to be used as?
qa_pairs.answer: A barrier ousting the constitutional control of fundamental rights.

qa_pairs.question: What did the Court state is 'dangerous' regarding exonerating corporations from constitutional conscience?
qa_pairs.answer: It is dangerous to exonerate corporations from the need to have constitutional conscience.

qa_pairs.question: Which interpretation should the court adopt regarding governmental agencies and constitutional limitations?
qa_pairs.answer: The interpretation, language permitting, which makes governmental agencies whatever their mein amenable to constitutional limitations.

qa_pairs.question: In which case was the above exposition taken as a guideline for examining if a private corporation falls under Article 12?
qa_pairs.answer: Som Prakash vs Union of India.

qa_pairs.question: To assess the functional role of private corporations in chemicals and fertilizers, what did the Court need to examine?
qa_pairs.answer: The Industrial Policy of the Government and the public interest importance given by the State to such activities.

qa_pairs.question: Under the Industrial Policy Resolution 1956, how were industries classified?
qa_pairs.answer: Into three categories based on the State's role in each.

qa_pairs.question: Which category of industries was to be the exclusive responsibility of the State under the 1956 Resolution?
qa_pairs.answer: The first category.

qa_pairs.question: What characterized the second category of industries under the 1956 Resolution?
qa_pairs.answer: Progressive State ownership, with the State generally taking the initiative but private enterprise also expected to supplement efforts.

qa_pairs.question: What characterized the third category of industries under the 1956 Resolution?
qa_pairs.answer: All remaining industries, with future development generally left to private initiative.

legal_cases.judgement:
ivil Appeal No. 3006 of 1981.
From the Judgment and Order dated 28.7.1981 of the Himachal Pradesh High Court in C.W.P. No. 94 of 1981.
M.V. Goswami for the Appellant.
Nemo for the Respondents.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KULDIP SINGH, J.
"Nautor land" under Rule 3 of the Himachal Pradesh Nautor Land Rules, 1968 (hereinafter called 'Rules ') means the right to utilize with the sanction of the competent authority, waste land owned by the Government outside the towns, outside the reserved and demarcated protected forests, and outside such other areas as may be notified from time to time by the State Government.
Gopinder Singh applied for the grant of nautor land measuring 14 bighas 12 biswas situated in village Kanal for cultivation.
The Revenue Assistant Chopal vide his order dated June 29, 1972 sanctioned nautor land measuring 11 bighas 1 biswas situated in village Kanal to him on payment of Rs.552.50 as Nazarana.
The Forest Department filed an appeal against the said order before the Deputy Commissioner Simla which was accepted and the order of the Revenue As sistant Chopal sanctioning nautor land in favour of Gopinder Singh was set aside.
Gopinder Singh filed further appeal to Divisional Com missioner, Himachal Pradesh at Simla who accepted the same and vide his order dated September 9, 1974 restored the grant of nautor land to Gopinder Singh.
The Forest Depart ment filed revision petition before the Financial Commis sioner (Revenue Appeals) Himachal Pradesh who accepted the revision petition and set aside the order dated September 9, 1974 of the Divisional Commissioner sanctioning nautor land to Gopinder Singh.
He further ordered that the amount of Nazarana Should.
be refunded to Gopinder Singh and the land resumed to the State.
The Financial Commissioner accepted the appeal on the following two grounds: 799 (1) Gopinder Singh felled the trees on the land without waiting for necessary approval of the Divisional Forest Officer and as such he took the law in his own hands.
(2) Being a teacher in a Government school drawing month ly emoluments of more than Rs.650 p.m. his economic condi tion was reasonably good and as such he was not eligible for the grant of nautor land under the Rules.
Against the order of the Financial Commissioner Gopinder Singh filed Civil Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India before the High Court of Himachal Pradesh at Simla which was dismissed in limine on July 28, 1981.
This appeal by special leave is by appellant Gopinder Singh against the orders of the Financial Commissioner and of the High Court.
Rule 7 of the Rules lays down the categories of persons eligible for the grant of nautor land.
The said rule is as under: "Eligibility for nautor land.
Save for the widow and the children of a member of an armed force or semi armed force, who has laid down his life for the country (whose widow and children will be eligible for grant anywhere within the Tehsil subject to the conditions mentioned in the Wajib ul arj in respect of the areas where the land applied for is situated) no one who is not the resident in the estate in which the land applied for is situate, shall be eligible for the grant.
Every resident of the estate in which the land applied for lies will be eligible in the following order of preference: (a) Such persons who have less than ten bighas of land, whether as owners, or as tenants, or as lessees, either individually or collectively, or have an income of less than Rs.2,000 per annum from all sources including lands.
Provid ed that in this category a dependent of one who has laid down his life for the defence of the country shall get preference over his counterparts; (b) Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes applicants; (c) The dependants of those who have laid down their lives for the defence of the country.
Service for the defence of 800 the country will mean service in a uniformed force as well as in the capacity of civilian, so long as the death occurs on a front, be it military or civil; (d) Serving personnel in the armed forces and Ex servicemen; (e) Panchayats, and (f) others; Provided that a bona fide landless resident of Spite shall be eligible for the grant of land in Nautor within the spiti Sub Division.
" The learned counsel appearing for the appellant has relied on first part of clause (a) of Rule 7 to show that the appellant was having less than 10 bighas of land and as such as was eligible for the grant of nautor land.
He fur ther contended that even though he may be having an income of more than Rs.2,000 per annum as a teacher, he being eligible under the first part, the second part of clause (a) of Rule 7 is not attracted in his case.
According to him first and the second part of clause (a) of Rule 7 are inde pendent to each other and there being 'or ' in between the two parts these have to be read disjunctively.
He contends that 'or ' has to be given its ordinary meaning and it cannot be read as 'and '.
We have carefully examined the provisions of clause (a) of Rule 7 reproduced above.
The clause reads "such persons who have less than 10 bighas of land . or have an income of less than 2,000 per annum from all sources including lands.
" There is thus inherent evidence in the clause itself to show that the two parts cannot be read disjunctively.
The second part makes it clear that an income of less than Rs.2,000 per annum should be from all sources including lands.
It is thus obvious that a person who has got less than 10 bighas of land but has an income of more than Rs.2,000 from the said land, is not eligible for allotment of nautor land under clause (a).
Even otherwise if we inter pret the clause the way learned counsel for the appellant wants us to do it would produce absurd result.
A person have two bighas of land but otherwise earning Rs.20,000 per annum would be eligible for allotment of nautor land if we accept the appellant 's interpretation.
The object of granting nautor land under the rules is to help poor and unprovided for residents of Himachal Pradesh.
Considering the nature, scope and the clear intention of the framers of the Rules it is 801 necessary to read the word "or" in between the first and the second part of clause (a) as "and".
The appellant 's income was admittedly more than Rs.2,000 per annum and as such his claim for nautor land was rightly rejected.
We, therefore, do not agree with the contentions raised by the learned counsel for the appellant.
The appeal is, therefore, dismissed with no order as to costs.
P.S.S. Appeal dis missed.

qa_pairs.question: What was the number of the Civil Appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: The number of the Civil Appeal was 3006 of 1981.

qa_pairs.question: From which High Court and what was the date of the judgment being appealed?
qa_pairs.answer: The appeal was from the Judgment and Order dated 28.7.1981 of the Himachal Pradesh High Court.

qa_pairs.question: What was the number of the Civil Writ Petition in the Himachal Pradesh High Court?
qa_pairs.answer: The number of the Civil Writ Petition was 94 of 1981.

qa_pairs.question: Who was the advocate representing the Appellant?
qa_pairs.answer: M.V. Goswami was the advocate for the Appellant.

qa_pairs.question: Who represented the Respondents?
qa_pairs.answer: Nemo represented the Respondents.

qa_pairs.question: Who delivered the Judgment of the Court?
qa_pairs.answer: Justice Kuldip Singh delivered the Judgment of the Court.

qa_pairs.question: What does 'Nautor land' mean under Rule 3 of the Himachal Pradesh Nautor Land Rules, 1968?
qa_pairs.answer: It means the right to utilize, with the sanction of the competent authority, waste land owned by the Government outside towns, reserved/protected forests, and other notified areas.

qa_pairs.question: Who applied for the grant of nautor land and how much?
qa_pairs.answer: Gopinder Singh applied for 14 bighas 12 biswas of nautor land in village Kanal.

qa_pairs.question: What was the order of the Revenue Assistant Chopal regarding the nautor land?
qa_pairs.answer: He sanctioned 11 bighas 1 biswas of nautor land in village Kanal to Gopinder Singh on payment of Rs. 552.50 as Nazarana.

qa_pairs.question: Which authority filed an appeal against the Revenue Assistant's order?
qa_pairs.answer: The Forest Department filed an appeal.

qa_pairs.question: What was the decision of the Deputy Commissioner Simla on the Forest Department's appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: The Deputy Commissioner accepted the appeal and set aside the Revenue Assistant's order.

qa_pairs.question: What was Gopinder Singh's next course of action after the Deputy Commissioner's order?
qa_pairs.answer: He filed a further appeal to the Divisional Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh at Simla.

qa_pairs.question: What was the decision of the Divisional Commissioner on Gopinder Singh's appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: The Divisional Commissioner accepted the appeal and restored the grant of nautor land to Gopinder Singh.

qa_pairs.question: Which authority filed a revision petition against the Divisional Commissioner's order?
qa_pairs.answer: The Forest Department filed a revision petition before the Financial Commissioner (Revenue Appeals) Himachal Pradesh.

qa_pairs.question: What was the decision of the Financial Commissioner on the revision petition?
qa_pairs.answer: The Financial Commissioner accepted the revision petition and set aside the Divisional Commissioner's order, ordering refund of Nazarana and resumption of the land to the State.

qa_pairs.question: What were the two grounds on which the Financial Commissioner accepted the appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: (1) Gopinder Singh felled trees without necessary approval, and (2) Being a government school teacher with a monthly income over Rs. 650, his economic condition was reasonably good, making him ineligible under the Rules.

qa_pairs.question: What action did Gopinder Singh take against the Financial Commissioner's order?
qa_pairs.answer: He filed a Civil Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India before the Himachal Pradesh High Court at Simla.

qa_pairs.question: What was the decision of the Himachal Pradesh High Court on Gopinder Singh's writ petition?
qa_pairs.answer: The High Court dismissed the writ petition in limine on July 28, 1981.

qa_pairs.question: Who is the appellant in this special leave appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: The appellant is Gopinder Singh.

qa_pairs.question: Against whose orders is this special leave appeal filed?
qa_pairs.answer: It is against the orders of the Financial Commissioner and the High Court.

qa_pairs.question: Which rule of the Himachal Pradesh Nautor Land Rules, 1968 lays down the categories of eligible persons?
qa_pairs.answer: Rule 7 of the Rules lays down the categories of eligible persons.

qa_pairs.question: According to Rule 7, who is generally ineligible for the grant of nautor land?
qa_pairs.answer: No one who is not a resident in the estate where the land applied for is situated is generally eligible.

qa_pairs.question: What is the exception to the residency requirement under Rule 7?
qa_pairs.answer: The widow and children of a member of an armed force or semi-armed force who laid down their life for the country are eligible anywhere within the Tehsil, subject to conditions in the Wajib ul arj.

qa_pairs.question: What is the first preference category for eligible residents under Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: Persons with less than ten bighas of land (as owners, tenants, or lessees, individually or collectively) or an annual income less than Rs. 2,000 from all sources including lands.

qa_pairs.question: What preference is given within the first category under Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: A dependent of one who laid down their life for the defense of the country gets preference over their counterparts.

qa_pairs.question: What are the subsequent categories of preference under Rule 7?
qa_pairs.answer: (b) Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes applicants; (c) Dependants of those who laid down their lives for the defence of the country; (d) Serving personnel in the armed forces and Ex-servicemen; (e) Panchayats; and (f) others.

qa_pairs.question: What does 'service for the defence of the country' mean under Rule 7(c)?
qa_pairs.answer: Service in a uniformed force as well as in the capacity of civilian, as long as the death occurs on a front, be it military or civil.

qa_pairs.question: What is the special provision for bona fide landless residents of Spiti under Rule 7?
qa_pairs.answer: They are eligible for the grant of land in Nautor within the Spiti Sub Division.

qa_pairs.question: On which part of Rule 7 did the appellant's counsel rely to argue the appellant's eligibility?
qa_pairs.answer: The first part of clause (a) of Rule 7, stating the appellant had less than 10 bighas of land.

qa_pairs.question: What was the appellant's counsel's argument regarding his income as a teacher?
qa_pairs.answer: He argued that even if his income was over Rs. 2,000 per annum, he was eligible under the first part of Rule 7(a), making the second part inapplicable.

qa_pairs.question: According to the appellant's counsel, how should the two parts of Rule 7(a) be read?
qa_pairs.answer: Independently and disjunctively due to the presence of 'or' between them.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Court's interpretation of the word 'or' in Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court interpreted 'or' as 'and' in this context.

qa_pairs.question: What evidence within Rule 7(a) did the Court point to, suggesting the two parts should not be read disjunctively?
qa_pairs.answer: The second part clarifies that the income limit of Rs. 2,000 per annum should be from all sources including lands, implying a connection to landholding.

qa_pairs.question: What absurd result did the Court say would occur if the appellant's interpretation of Rule 7(a) was accepted?
qa_pairs.answer: A person with two bighas of land but earning Rs. 20,000 per annum would be eligible for nautor land.

qa_pairs.question: What is the stated object of granting nautor land under the Rules?
qa_pairs.answer: To help poor and unprovided for residents of Himachal Pradesh.

qa_pairs.question: Considering the object of the Rules, how did the Court find it necessary to read the word 'or' in Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: As 'and'.

qa_pairs.question: What was the admitted fact regarding the appellant's annual income?
qa_pairs.answer: His income was admittedly more than Rs. 2,000 per annum.

qa_pairs.question: Based on his income, was the appellant's claim for nautor land considered rightly rejected?
qa_pairs.answer: Yes, the Court found his claim was rightly rejected.

qa_pairs.question: Did the Court agree with the contentions raised by the appellant's counsel?
qa_pairs.answer: No, the Court did not agree with the contentions.

qa_pairs.question: What was the final order of the Court regarding the appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: The appeal was dismissed.

qa_pairs.question: Was there any order as to costs?
qa_pairs.answer: There was no order as to costs.

qa_pairs.question: What was the year of the Himachal Pradesh Nautor Land Rules?
What was the date of the Himachal Pradesh High Court's judgment?
Who was Gopinder Singh?
qa_pairs.answer: He was the applicant for the grant of nautor land and the appellant in this appeal.

qa_pairs.question: What is 'Nazarana' in the context of the judgment?
qa_pairs.answer: It is the payment Gopinder Singh was required to make for the sanctioned nautor land.

qa_pairs.question: What was the area of nautor land initially sanctioned to Gopinder Singh by the Revenue Assistant?
qa_pairs.answer: 11 bighas 1 biswas.

qa_pairs.question: Which village was the nautor land situated in?
qa_pairs.answer: Village Kanal.

qa_pairs.question: What was the role of the Divisional Forest Officer mentioned in the Financial Commissioner's order?
qa_pairs.answer: His necessary approval was not obtained by Gopinder Singh before felling trees.

qa_pairs.question: What was the appellant's profession?
qa_pairs.answer: He was a teacher in a Government school.

qa_pairs.question: What was the monthly income threshold mentioned by the Financial Commissioner for eligibility?
qa_pairs.answer: More than Rs. 650 per month.

qa_pairs.question: Under which Article of the Constitution was the writ petition filed in the High Court?
qa_pairs.answer: Article 226.

qa_pairs.question: What is the meaning of 'in limine' in the context of the High Court's dismissal?
qa_pairs.answer: It means the writ petition was dismissed at the threshold without a full hearing.

qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of 'bighas' and 'biswas' in the judgment?
qa_pairs.answer: They are units of land measurement used in Himachal Pradesh.

qa_pairs.question: What is 'Wajib ul arj' mentioned in Rule 7?
qa_pairs.answer: It refers to the record of rights and customs in respect of the areas where the land is situated.

qa_pairs.question: What is the income limit mentioned in Rule 7(a) for eligibility?
qa_pairs.answer: Less than Rs. 2,000 per annum from all sources including lands.

qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of 'dependent of one who has laid down his life for the defence of the country' in Rule 7(a) and (c)?
qa_pairs.answer: They are given preference in the grant of nautor land.

qa_pairs.question: What are 'Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes' in the context of Rule 7(b)?
qa_pairs.answer: They are constitutionally recognized socially disadvantaged groups who are given preference in the grant of nautor land.

qa_pairs.question: Who are 'Ex-servicemen' mentioned in Rule 7(d)?
qa_pairs.answer: Persons who have previously served in the armed forces.

qa_pairs.question: What are 'Panchayats' in the context of Rule 7(e)?
qa_pairs.answer: Local self-government institutions at the village level.

qa_pairs.question: What is 'Spiti Sub Division' mentioned in the proviso to Rule 7?
qa_pairs.answer: A specific administrative division where a special eligibility rule applies to landless residents.

qa_pairs.question: What was the appellant's argument regarding the use of 'or' in the eligibility criteria?
qa_pairs.answer: He argued it should be read disjunctively, meaning fulfilling either the landholding or the income criteria would suffice for eligibility.

qa_pairs.question: What was the Court's reasoning for rejecting the disjunctive reading of 'or'?
qa_pairs.answer: The context of the clause, especially the inclusion of 'including lands' in the income criteria, suggested a conjunctive reading ('and') was intended to benefit the truly poor and unprovided.

qa_pairs.question: What did the Court emphasize as the primary objective of the Nautor Land Rules?
qa_pairs.answer: To assist the poor and unprovided for residents of Himachal Pradesh.

qa_pairs.question: What was the ultimate basis for the Court's dismissal of the appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: The appellant's admitted income being above the eligibility threshold when the rule was interpreted to require both low landholding and low income.

qa_pairs.question: What does the term 'estate' refer to in the context of Rule 7?
qa_pairs.answer: It refers to the local area or jurisdiction where the land applied for is situated and where residency is generally required for eligibility.

qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of the 'Provid ed that' clause within Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: It introduces a specific condition or exception within the main rule, in this case, granting preference to dependents of those who sacrificed their lives for the nation.

qa_pairs.question: What does the phrase 'bona fide landless resident of Spiti' imply?
qa_pairs.answer: It refers to a genuine resident of the Spiti region who does not own any land.

qa_pairs.question: Why was the appellant's status as a government teacher relevant to the case?
qa_pairs.answer: It was relevant because his income from this profession exceeded the income limit set in Rule 7(a) for eligibility.

qa_pairs.question: What was the core issue of interpretation before the Supreme Court?
qa_pairs.answer: The correct interpretation of the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 7(a) of the Himachal Pradesh Nautor Land Rules, 1968, specifically the meaning of 'or' in the landholding and income conditions.

qa_pairs.question: Did the Supreme Court consider the intention behind the Nautor Land Rules?
qa_pairs.answer: Yes, the Court explicitly considered the object of the rules, which was to help poor and unprovided for residents.

qa_pairs.question: How did the Court use the stated object of the rules in its interpretation?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court used the object to justify reading 'or' as 'and', as a disjunctive reading would not serve the purpose of assisting the truly needy.

qa_pairs.question: What was the appellant's argument regarding the independence of the two parts of Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: He argued that having less than 10 bighas of land was sufficient for eligibility, regardless of his income.

qa_pairs.question: What was the Court's counter-argument to the appellant's interpretation of Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: The Court pointed to the phrase 'from all sources including lands' in the income part, indicating that income from land was also to be considered, thus linking the two conditions.

qa_pairs.question: Did the Court find any ambiguity in the language of Rule 7(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: While the appellant argued for an ambiguity based on the word 'or', the Court found inherent evidence to suggest a conjunctive reading was more appropriate in the context of the rule's objective.

qa_pairs.question: What was the practical consequence of the Court's interpretation for the appellant?
qa_pairs.answer: Since his income exceeded the limit, he was deemed ineligible for the grant of nautor land, despite having less than 10 bighas of land.

qa_pairs.question: Was the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition upheld by the Supreme Court?
qa_pairs.answer: Yes, the Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, effectively upholding the High Court's decision.

qa_pairs.question: Did the Supreme Court go into the merits of the Financial Commissioner's other ground for rejection (felling of trees)?
qa_pairs.answer: The judgment primarily focused on the interpretation of the eligibility criteria based on landholding and income, so the other ground was not extensively discussed by the Supreme Court.

qa_pairs.question: What does 'special leave' imply in the context of this appeal?
qa_pairs.answer: It means that the Supreme Court granted permission to the appellant to appeal the High Court's order, as appeals are not automatically granted.

qa_pairs.question: What is the role of the 'Financial Commissioner (Revenue Appeals)' in the administrative hierarchy related to land matters in Himachal Pradesh?
qa_pairs.answer: The Financial Commissioner is a high-ranking administrative authority who hears appeals and revisions in revenue matters, including land grants.

qa_pairs.question: What is the significance of 'Rule 3' being mentioned in the definition of 'Nautor land'?
qa_pairs.answer: It indicates that the definition itself is provided within the Himachal Pradesh Nautor Land Rules, 1968.

qa_pairs.question: What does 'competent authority' likely refer to in the context of sanctioning Nautor land?
qa_pairs.answer: It likely refers to the specific revenue officials authorized under the Nautor Land Rules to approve the utilization of such land.

qa_pairs.question: What is the general nature of 'waste land owned by the Government' that can be classified as Nautor land?
qa_pairs.answer: It is government-owned land that is not currently under cultivation or any specific reservation (like forests) and is available for utilization under the Nautor Land Rules.

qa_pairs.question: What is the purpose of having an 'order of preference' in Rule 7 for eligible residents?
qa_pairs.answer: It establishes a hierarchy among eligible applicants, ensuring that the most deserving categories (e.g., those with the least land or income) are considered first.

qa_pairs.question: What does the dismissal of the appeal 'with no order as to costs' mean?
qa_pairs.answer: It means that while the appellant lost the appeal, the Court did not impose any obligation on them to pay the legal costs of the respondents.

legal_cases.judgement:
ivil Appeals Nos.
1270 & 1317 1319 of 1970.
From the Judgment and Order dated 5 2 1970 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in L. P. A. Nos.
96 99 of 1966.
Kapil Sibal, J. B. Dadachanji and Shri Narain for the Appellant.
section Manchanda, Mrs. Shobha Dikshit and Mrs. Urmila Kapoor for the Respondents.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by FAZAL ALI, J.
These appeals by certificate are directed against a Common judgment dated February 5, 1970 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court by which a Letters Patent Appeal against a decision of the Single Judge was dismissed.
The facts of the case lie within a narrow compass and all the appeals involve a short point of law relating to the interpretation of s.9 of the Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 (hereinafter referred to as the 'Act ').
The history of the case has been detailed in the judgment of the High Court and it is not necessary for us to repeat the same.
Shorn of unnecessary details the appeals arose out of applications made by Pera Ram.
Ganga Ram, Bhago and Kalu Ram who were the tenants of agricultural land owned by Mrs. Raj Kanta, the appellant in these appeals.
The tenants made separate applications under section 18 of the Act on September 4, 1961 for purchasing the land held by them from Mrs. Raj Kanta (hereinafter called the 'land owner ').
These applications were allowed by the Assistant Collector on October 31, 1961.
Accordingly, the tenants deposited the 1009 first instalment in November 1961.
Ultimately, however, the tenants did not pay the rent of the respective holdings for Kharif 1961.
It is common ground that the last date by which the rent for Kharif 1961 was payable by the tenants to the land owner was January 15, 1962 and that the tenant did not pay the rent and did not show sufficient cause for the same.
In view of the default, the land owner filed separate applications under s.9(1) (ii) of the Act on the ground that as the tenants had failed to pay the rent regularly without sufficient cause, they were entitled to be ejected by the land owner.
The applications for ejectment were, however, dismissed but on appeal the Collector allowed the appeals by his order dated May 31, 1962.
Second appeals preferred by the tenants in the ejectment proceedings were dismissed by an order dated 5.11.62 of the Commissioner and ultimately upheld by the Financial Commissioner by his Order dated December 21, 1962.
Having failed before the Revenue courts, the tenants respondents filed a writ petition in the High Court which was heard by a Single Judge.
But in the case of Kalu Ram the Financial Commissioner allowed the petition and rejected the prayer for his ejectment by the land owner as a result of which the land owner filed a writ petition in the High Court.
All the petitions were consolidated and heard together, by the single Judge who allowed the writ petition of the tenants and quashed the order of the Financial Commissioner directing ejectment of the tenants.
The writ petition of the land owner against Kalu Ram was, however, dismissed.
Hence, the four appeals by the land owner appellant in this Court.
The only point that has been canvassed before us is as to whether or not the High Court was right in interpreting s.9 of the Act by holding that the term 'regularly ' used in s.9(1) (ii) would not include a single default.
While the Revenue courts had held that the mere fact that the tenants made a single default in payment for the rent for Kharif 1961 was sufficient to attract the penalty of ejectment envisaged by section 9(1) (ii) of the Act, the High Court took the view that on a proper interpretation of the term 'regularly ' it will appear that the legislature did not contemplate that ejectment should be ordered straightaway even if a single default, though unexplained, is committed by the tenant which interpretation would run against the avowed object of the legislation which was to advance and ameliorate the lot of the tenants.
The High Court had considered the matter at very great length and placed a very wide interpretation on the term 'regularly ' so as not to include within its ambit one single default.
It has also referred to a number of authorities and Dictionaries to 1010 show that the word 'regularly ' does not mean absolute symmetry.
Having gone through the reasons given by the High Court we are unable to agree with the view taken either by the single Judge or the Division Bench of the High Court.
There can be no doubt that the Act is a piece of social legislation meant to ameliorate the lot of the tenants and to further the rights of the tenants by conferring on them the status of a permanent tenancy or the rights to purchase the land on payment of instalments.
At the same time, we cannot overlook the fact that the landlords within a very limited sphere have been assured protection in respect of the rights which they possess in the land and have been given the right to eject the tenants on specified grounds which are contained in the various sub clauses of section 9 of the Act.
One such sub clause is sub clause (ii) which falls for interpretation in the instant case.
Section 9(1) as also clauses (i) and (ii) may be extracted thus: "9.
Liability of tenant to be ejected: 1.
Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, no land owner shall be competent to eject a tenant except when such tenant (i) is a tenant on the area reserved under this Act or is a tenant of a small land owner; (or) (ii) fails to pay rent regularly without sufficient cause; . " While interpreting the word 'regularly ' the High Court seems to have overlooked two important circumstances.
In the first place, the word 'regularly ' has been used immediately after the phrase 'fails to pay rent ' and is followed by the words 'without sufficient cause '.
Secondly, there is nothing in the section to indicate that the legislature intended to exclude one single default.
The High Court attempted to supply words to the section which are not there.
In doing so it has failed to consider that if once the court was to lay down a particular line of demarcation by extending the connotation of the word 'regularly ' to exclude one default, it is difficult to explain why the legislature contemplated only one default and not two or three for that matter.
In order to construe the plain language of s.9(1) (ii) which admits of no ambiguity, it may be necessary to look to the object and the purposes of the Act.
In the case of Bhagirath Ram Chand vs State of Punjab & Ors.
a full Bench of the Punjab & Haryana High Court held that the Preamble of the Act stated that it was intended to provide for the security of land tenure and other incidental matters.
It 1011 is no doubt true that the main thrust of the provisions of the Act are directed towards preventing the landlords from ejecting their tenants except on the grounds mentioned in s.9, but at the same time, it cannot be denied that the legislature undoubtedly provided some protection to the landlords by conferring on them a limited right to eject their tenants and within this limited sphere, the right was absolute and could not be curtailed by interpreting clause (ii) of section 9(1) of the Act through a process of twisting the law and doing violence to the language of the section.
To begin with, the word 'regular ' is derived form the word 'regula ' which means 'rule ' and its first and legitimate signification, according to Webster, is 'conformable to a rule, or agreeable to an established rule, law, or principle, to a prescribed mode.
In Words and Phrases (Vol.
36A, p.241) the word 'regular ' has been defined as 'steady or uniform in course, practice or occurrence, etc., and implies conformity to a rule, standard, or pattern '.
It is further stated in the said Book that 'regular ' means steady or uniform in course, practice, or occurrence; not subject to unexplained or irrational variation.
The word 'regular ' means in a regular manner, methodically, in due order.
Similarly, Webster 's New World Dictionary defines 'regular ' as 'consistent or habitual in action, not changing, uniform, conforming to a standard or to a generally accepted rule or mode of conduct: In the case of Arab Bank Ld. vs Ross while construing the words 'complete and regular ', Romer LJ observed as follows: "It wold accordingly follow, in my judgment, in the present case that the omission of the word "company" from the endorsement would reasonably give rise to a doubt whether in point of personality the payees and the indorsers were necessarily the same; and if so the bills cannot, as I think, be said to be "complete and regular" on their face.
" The view of the Judge clearly indicates that the word 'regular ' postulates a state of symmetry, consistency and uniformity.
In Hammond vs London County Council while construing the term "regularly employed", Farwell J. observed as follows: "It is of course a question of fact in each case whether a man was regularly employed or not, but in this particular case I think that the plaintiff, who was employed for the five years and paid his wages day in and day out during that period as a servant or officer of the defendants ' predecessors, was "regularly employed" during that period.
" 1012 This interpretation also supports our view that the word 'regular ' means a consistent course of conduct without any break or breach.
On a consideration of the authorities mentioned above, it seems to us that the legislature clearly intended to use the word 'regularly ' to mean payment of rent in a uniform and consistent manner without any breach or default.
The legislature never contemplated that a single default could be condoned.
This inference is fortified by the words "without sufficient cause".
In other words, the legislature clearly provided that if the tenant had committed a default, whether one, two or more, the same could only be condoned if sufficient cause is shown and not otherwise.
If, however, we accept the interpretation of the High Court, then the words "sufficient cause" becomes, absolutely redundant.
On an overall consideration of the matter, a correct interpretation of the plain language and the words and phrases used in clause (ii) of s.9(1) of the Act seems to us that the word 'regular ' connotes a consistent course of conduct without any break or breach and the words 'regular payment of rent ' mean that the rent should be paid punctually without any default or laxity.
Although the Act is heavily loaded in favour of the rights of the tenants so as to confer on them several important benefits and privileges yet as the Act is confiscatory in nature, so far as the landlord is concerned it should be strictly construed within the limited sphere inasmuch as the landlord is conferred limited grounds on which ejectment is permissible under s.9 of the Act which appears to be a safety valve for the limited rights that are left with the landlord under the Act.
In order therefore to advance the object of the Act so as to assure the limited protection to the landlord, the language employed in the various clauses of section 9 has to be construed so as to give real benefit to the landlord within the limited range that the section operates.
In the instant case, the words 'failure to pay rent regularly without sufficient cause ' postulate the following conditions: (1) there must be a failure on the part of the tenant to pay rent; (2) such failure must be to pay rent regularly, that is to say, the rent should be paid punctually consistently without any break or breach; (3) if there is any default ranging from one to several, the tenant has got to show sufficient cause if his case is to be taken out of the mischief of section 9(1) (ii).
1013 We might add at the risk of repetition that the use of the words `without sufficient cause ' clearly indicates that the intention of the legislature was that in order to escape ejectment, the tenant must at least be regular in payment of the rent and if he wants to get rid of the consequences of his default, he must prove sufficient cause.
If, however, we construe the word `regularly ' as meaning at regular intervals so as to include a single default, then the term `without sufficient cause ' becomes absolutely redundant.
For instance, even if a single default in the payment of the rent is committed by the tenant, his case could be taken out of the ambit of clause (ii) of section 9(1) without insisting on the tenant to prove sufficient cause for this single default.
That would, therefore, make the words `sufficient cause ' meaningless in such cases.
It is well settled that the legislature does not waste words and every word that is used by it must be presumed to have some significance.
The function of the Court, says Sir Fracis Bacon, is "jus decere and not jus dare" (to interpret the law and not to make the law).
The Court cannot, therefore, in order to promote its social philosophy turn and twist the plain and unambiguous language of the law so as to ascribe to it a meaning different from the one intended by the legislature.
We are constrained to observe, with due respect, that this is what the High Court seems to have done in this case by adopting a puerile and pedantic process of reasoning.
In these circumstances, reading the entire sentence, the cumulative effect thereof unmistakably is that the Act includes even a single default and that is why instead of using the word `default ' the word `regularly ' has been employed which is immediately followed by the words `without sufficient cause '.
Moreover, we might mention that in the various Rent Acts passed in the States, ejectment is permissible in some cases where there is a single default, in other cases where there is more than one default and so on.
If the legislature intended that a single default would not entitle a landlord to eject the tenant under the Act, then it would have said so expressly either by way of an explanation or otherwise in clause (ii) of section 9(1) of the Act.
Finally, we cannot lose sight of the explanation used for the various clauses of section 9(1) which runs thus : "Explanation.
For the purposes of clause (iii), a tenant shall be deemed to be in arrears of rent at the commencement of this Act, only if the payment of arrears is not made by the tenant within a period of two months from the date of notice of the execution of decree or order, directing him to pay such arrears of rent.
" While the explanation takes care to define as to when a tenant would be deemed to be in arrears and fixes a period of two months, 1014 indeed if the intention of the legislature was that a single default in payment of rent could be condoned, it should have included this incident also in the explanation.
This provides, therefore, the most important intrinsic circumstance to support the interpretation which we have put on clause (ii) of s.9(1) of the Act and which invalidates the reasons given by the High Court.
For the reasons given above, we are satisfied that the High Court took an erroneous view of law in interpreting clause (ii) of section 9(1) of the Act as the tenants have been proved, in this case, to have committed default in the payment of rent for Kharif 1961, they must be held to have failed to pay the rent regularly without sufficient cause as envisaged by clause (ii) and are, therefore, legally entitled to ejectment.
